sentences.sentence: They were again silent, until he asked her if she and her sisters often walked to Meryton.
She answered that they did.
Unable to resist( 抵挡 ) the temptation( 诱惑 ), she added, “When you met us there the other day, we had just been making a new acquaintance( 相识 ).”
The effect was immediate.
A look of hurt pride spread across his face, but he did not say a word.
Elizabeth, though she blamed herself for her own weakness, could not continue.
Eventually Darcy, with an obvious effort to control his feelings, said, “Mr. Wickham is lucky to have such a happy way of speaking,
that he may always be sure of making friends.
Whether he is equally capable of( 能够 ) keeping them, is less certain.”
“He has been unlucky enough to lose your friendship,” replied Elizabeth with emphasis( 强调 ), “and in a way which he is likely to suffer from all his life.”
Darcy made no answer, and seemed as if he wanted to change the subject.
“What do you think of books?” he said, smiling.
“Books?
Oh! No, I am sure we never read the same ones, or that we cannot agree on them.”
“I am sorry you think so, but if that is true, then at least we will have plenty to discuss.
We may compare our different opinions.”
“No—I cannot talk of books in a ball-room.
I am always thinking of something else.”
“The present moment always fills your thoughts in such scenes—does it?” he said, with a look of doubt.
“Yes, always,” she replied.
Her thoughts had wandered far from the subject, and soon afterward( 之后 ) she found herself saying, “I remember hearing you once say, Mr. Darcy, that you hardly ever forgave.
You must then be very cautious( 谨慎的 ), I suppose, about when you decide to resent( 怨恨 ) someone.”
“I am,” said he, with a firm voice.
“And you never allow yourself to be blinded by prejudice( 偏见 )?”
“I hope not.
May I ask what these questions are about?”
“Merely to better understand your character,” said she.
“I am trying to figure it out.”
“And may I ask if you have succeeded?”
She shook her head.
“I do not understand you at all.
I have heard such different accounts of you that I am exceedingly( 极其 ) puzzled( 疑惑的 ).”
“I can easily believe,” he answered seriously,
“that reports about me may vary( 变化 ) greatly.
I hope that you will not make any decisions about my character at the present moment.
There is reason to fear that such judgment might not show either of us at our best.”
“But if I do not form any idea of your character now, I may never have another opportunity.”
“I would by no means( 一点也不 ) prevent you from doing whatever you choose to do,” he coldly replied.
She said no more, and they finished their dance and parted in silence, with both leaving dissatisfied.
As Elizabeth no longer had any interest of her own to pursue( 追问 ), she turned her attention almost entirely toward her sister and Mr. Bingley.
The thoughts which occurred to her while observing them made her perhaps almost as happy as Jane.
She imagined Jane living here at Netherfield, enjoying all the happiness which a marriage of true affection could bring.
It was obvious to Elizabeth that her mother was thinking in the same way.
When they sat down to supper, Elizabeth was greatly annoyed to find that her mother was talking freely, openly, and of nothing else but her expectation that Jane would soon be married to Mr. Bingley.
It seemed Mrs. Bennet would never grow tired of( 厌倦 ) discussing the advantages of the marriage.
She boasted( 自吹自擂 ) of how he was such a charming( 迷人的 ) young man, and so rich, and lived only three miles from them.
She also could not help mentioning what an opportunity it would be for her younger daughters, since Jane’s marriage would allow them to meet with other rich men.
She concluded( 结束 ) her speech with many good wishes that others might soon be equally fortunate, though obviously and triumphantly( 得意洋洋地 ) believing there was no chance of it.
Elizabeth tried helplessly( 无助的 ) to persuade her mother to be quiet, because she could see that everything she said was overheard( 无意间听到 ) by Mr. Darcy, who sat opposite( 对面 ) to them.
Nothing that she could say,
however, had any effect: Mrs. Bennet simply replied, “Who is Mr. Darcy to me, that I should be afraid of him?
I am sure we owe( 给予 ) him no special civility.”
Elizabeth blushed( 脸红 ) and blushed again with shame.
She could not help frequently glancing at Mr. Darcy, and though he was not always looking at her mother,
she was convinced( 确信的 ) that his attention was focused on her the entire time.
The expression of his face changed gradually from indignant( 愤慨的 ) contempt( 蔑视 ) to a composed( 镇定的 ) and steady( 平稳的 ) seriousness.
At last, however, Mrs. Bennet had no more to say.
Elizabeth now began to recover, but she was not able to relax for long.
When supper was over, singing was mentioned, and she was horrified to see Mary preparing to perform.
Mary’s abilities were by no means( 一点也不 ) suitable for such a display( 展示 ).
Her voice was weak, and her style of singing was highly unsuitable for such a gathering.
Elizabeth was extremely uncomfortable.
She looked at her father to beg for him to interfere, in order to keep Mary from singing all night.
He took the hint( 暗示 ), and when Mary had finished her second song, he said aloud, “That will do extremely well, child.
You have delighted us long enough.
Let the other young ladies have time to perform.”
Mary was somewhat shocked.
Elizabeth felt sorry for her, and was afraid that her father, by criticizing( 批评 ) his own daughter so publicly, had done more harm than good to the family’s reputation( 名声 ).
To Elizabeth it seemed that, if her family had made an agreement to embarrass( 使...尴尬 ) themselves as much as possible during the evening,
they could not have done so any more successfully than they already had.
It was nearly unbearable that Mr. Darcy, as well as the rest of the company, now had such an opportunity to laugh at her relations.

article_info.previous: Elizabeth和Jane对Mr. Darcy的所作所为十分惊诧，Mr. Collins邀请Elizabeth跳舞，Elizabeth不情愿但是答应了，舞毕后Mr. Darcy竟然也来邀请Elizabeth，Elizabeth也稀里糊涂地答应了。
article_info.share_words: A look of hurt pride spread across his face, but he did not say a word. Elizabeth, though she blamed herself for her own weakness, could not continue.

question.cn: Mr. Darcy想和Elizabeth从哪个话题展开谈话？
question.en: On which topic did Mr. Darcy try to make conversation with Elizabeth?

analysis: 文中提到，“What do you think of books?”“Books? Oh! No, I am sure we never read the same ones, or that we cannot agree on them.”因此选C。

question.cn: 当他们坐下的时候Elizabeth的母亲在干什么？
question.en: What was Elizabeth's mother doing when they sat down?

options.cn: 她在谈论她女儿们的婚事。
options.en: She was talking about her daughter's marriage.

options.cn: 她在专注地享用她的餐食。

options.en: She was playing cards with Mr. Collins.

analysis: 文中提到：“When they sat down to supper, Elizabeth was greatly annoyed to find that her mother was talking......that Jane would soon be married to Mr. Bingley.” 所以选A。

question.cn: 为什么Elizabeth对Mary的歌声感到不舒服？
question.en: Why was Elizabeth uncomfortable with Mary's style of singing?

options.cn: 因为Mary唱得太好了，Elizabeth很嫉妒。
options.en: Because Mary sang so well that Elizabeth was jealous.
Because Elizabeth did not like the songs that she sang.

options.cn: 因为Mary的歌声不适合聚会。
options.en: Because Mary's singing was unsuitable for the gathering.

analysis: 文中提到：“Her voice was weak, and her style of singing was highly unsuitable for such a gathering. Elizabeth was extremely uncomfortable.” 所以选C。
